the von Klitzing constant which appears in the quantum Hall effect

qas.question: If the effects are valid, for RK = n/e2, what is the measurement of KJ2RK equal to?

plausible_answers.text: an instrument for comparing two powers, one of which is measured in SI watts and the other of which is measured in conventional electrical units

qas.question: What does a watt balance avoid?

plausible_answers.text: the von Klitzing constant which appears in the quantum Hall effect

qas.question: What is the measurement of KJ2RR equal to?

plausible_answers.text: the definition of the conventional watt W90

qas.question: What gives gives a measure of the product KJ2RR in SI units?

context: A watt balance is <a0_0><b3_0>an instrument for comparing two powers, one of which is measured in SI watts and the other of which is measured in conventional electrical units<b3_0/><a0_0/>. From <b6_0>the definition of the conventional watt W90<b6_0/>, this gives a measure of the product KJ2RK in SI units, where RK is <a1_0><b4_0>the von Klitzing constant which appears in the quantum Hall effect<b4_0/><a1_0/>. If the theoretical treatments of the Josephson effect and the quantum Hall effect are valid, and in particular assuming that RK = h/e2, the measurement of KJ2RK is a direct determination of <a2_0><b5_0>the Planck constant<b5_0/><a2_0/>.
